page.title: 01Hexden and Roter Levels
page.content: This area is flat, marshy grassland intersected from east to west by the Hexden Channel and River Rother. Most of the field boundaries are dikes, there are three isolated farms and a few scattered cottages. It has hardly changed in 150 years. The grazing is excellent for fattening sheep and cattle there are some wheatfields and natural woodland in the areas. Outsiders are attracted by the birdlife and fishing (though we have lately had a disastrous spillage from a wood treatment works on the Newmill Channel) by the attractive Kent and East Sussex Light Railway, now restored largely by volunteers, and by some archaeological sites, notable Newenden castle toll.
